entry.title: è‹±è¯­å¬åŠ›
entry.content:
Day 1

Pablo Escobarâ€™s Hippos Could Endanger Colombian Ecology

Around 115 miles east of MedellÃ­n, in Colombia, sits the enormous(å·¨å¤§) hacienda(ç‰§åœº) built by the drug lord Pablo Escobarâ€”who had his own personal zoo, which included hippos(æ²³é©¬). When Escobarâ€™s empire fell, most of the exotic(å¤–æ¥çš„) animals were safely relocatedâ€”except for the hippos, who eventually escaped.

â€œSo he brought four from a zoo in the U.S. to Colombia, and they lived at his ranch(ç‰§åœº). And theyâ€™ve grown slowly but steadily.â€

Jonathan Shurin, ecologist(ç”Ÿæ€å­¦å®¶) from the University of California in San Diego.

The original(æœ€åˆçš„) population of four in 1981 is estimated(ä¼°è®¡) to be at least 80 now. Hippos have a tremendous influence(å·¨å¤§å½±å“) on their native ecosystems(æœ¬åœŸç”Ÿæ€) in Africa, so Shurin wanted to see how they might be affecting their new ecosystem(ç”Ÿæ€ç³»ç»Ÿ) in Colombia.

â€œIt shouldnâ€™t be a surprise to anybody that hippos poop(ç²ªä¾¿) in the water in South America, just as they do in Africa.â€

Hippos on both continents wallow in ponds and lakes, where their droppings release a tremendous amount of nutrients into the water.

â€œThat imported material(è¾“å…¥çš„ç‰©è´¨) stimulates(åˆºæ¿€) photosynthesis of algae and aquatic plants(è—»ç±»å’Œæ°´ç”Ÿæ¤ç‰©çš„å…‰åˆä½œç”¨) and also microbial bacterial productionâ€”bacteria that are living off of the organic matter thatâ€™s imported.â€

And thatâ€™s where the hippos can cause ecological trouble. If there is too much photosynthesis(å…‰åˆä½œç”¨) occurring, then the water becomes full of oxygen during the daytime(ç™½å¤©). But at night, when the sun goes down, and the plants and algae stop releasing oxygen into the water, a phenomenon called eutrophication(å¯Œè¥å…»åŒ–) occurs. All the creatures that consume(æ¶ˆè€—) oxygen keep consuming it, and the overall amount of oxygen dissolved(æº¶è§£) in the water becomes critically(ä¸¥é‡çš„) low.

â€œThe oxygen dropping low enoughâ€”you can have all the fish sort of croaking and going belly-up(è‚šçš®æœä¸Š).â€

The researchers also say the situation provides(æä¾›) a unique glimpse(è§†è§’) into the way that massive mammals(å¤§å‹å“ºä¹³åŠ¨ç‰©) like mammoths and mastodons, long extinct(ç­ç»çš„) in the New World, may have influenced their habitats prior(åœ¨å‰çš„) to their extinction.

But they also note that unless we can somehow curtail(ç¼©å‡) their population growth, the hippo population could explode(çˆ†ç‚¸) in the next couple of decadesâ€”at which point, they will disrupt(ç ´å) larger and wilder river systems. The study is in the journal Ecology. [Jonathan B. Shurin et al., Ecosystem effects of the worldâ€™s largest invasive animal]

Lethal(è‡´å‘½çš„) control isnâ€™t a popular management strategy(ç­–ç•¥) among people who love hippos or see them as a valuable tourism attraction. But the question is when, not if, the hippos become detrimental(æœ‰å®³çš„) to Colombian ecologyâ€”which means that folks(äººä»¬) should be thinking about the best way to solve the problem now, when there are fewer than a hundred hippos to manage and not thousands.

â€”Jason G. Goldman
